Connection terminated. I'm sorry to interrupt you, Elizabeth, if you still even remember that name, but I'm afraid you've been misinformed. You are not here to receive a gift, nor have you been called here by the individual you assume. Although you have indeed been called. You have all been called here into a labyrinth of sounds and smells, misdirection and misfortune. A labyrinth with no exit, a maze with no prize. You don't even realize that you are trapped. Your lust for blood has driven you in endless circles, chasing the cries of children in some unseen chamber always seeming so near, yet somehow out of reach. But you will never find them. None of you will. This is where your story ends.

And to you, my brave volunteer, who somehow found this job listing not intended for you: although there was a way out planned for you, I have a feeling that's not what you want. I have a feeling that you are right where you want to be. I am remaining as well. I am nearby. This place will not be remembered, and the memory of everything that started this can finally begin to fade away, as the agony of every tragedy should.

And to you monsters trapped in the corridors, be still and give up your spirits. They don't belong to you. For most of you, I believe there is peace and perhaps more, waiting for you after the smoke clears. Although, for one of you, the darkest pit of Hell has opened to swallow you whole, so don't keep the Devil waiting, old friend.

My daughter, if you can hear me, I knew you would return as well. It's in your nature to protect the innocent. I'm sorry on that day, the day you were shut out and left to die, no one was there to lift you up into their arms the way you lifted others into yours. And then, what became of you. I should have known you wouldn't be content to disappear, not my daughter. I couldn't save you then, so let me save you now. It's time to rest; for you, and for those you have carried in your arms. This ends for all of us. End communication.

Connection terminated.

I'm sorry to interrupt you Elizabeth, if you still even remember that name. But I'm afraid you've been misinformed. You are not here to receive a gift, nor have you been called here by the individual you assume. Although you have indeed been called.

You have all been called here. Into a labyrinth of sounds and smells, misdirection and misfortune. A labyrinth with no exit, a maze with no prize. You don't even realize that you are trapped. Your lust for blood has driven you in endless circles, chasing the cries of children in some unseen chamber, always seeming so near, yet somehow out of reach.

But you will never find them, none of you will. This is where your story ends.

And to you, my brave volunteer, who somehow found this job listing not intended for you. Although there was a way out planned for you, I have a feeling that's not what you want. I have a feeling that you are right where you want to be. I am remaining as well, I am nearby.

This place will not be remembered, and the memory of everything that started this can finally begin to fade away. As the agony of every tragedy should. And to you monsters trapped in the corridors: Be still and give up your spirits, they don't belong to you.

For most of you, I believe there is peace and perhaps more waiting for you after the smoke clears. Although, for one of you, the darkest pit of Hell has opened to swallow you whole, so don't keep the devil waiting, old friend.

My daughter, if you can hear me, I knew you would return as well. It's in your nature to protect the innocent. I'm sorry that on that day, the day you were shut out and left to die, no one was there to lift you up into their arms the way you lifted others into yours. And then, what became of you.

I should have known you wouldn't be content to disappear, not my daughter. I couldn't save you then, so let me save you now.

It's time to rest. For you, and for those you have carried in your arms.

This ends for all of us.

End communication.

150120820.review:
This game is MISERABLE! in the first nights i was having fun but night 6 is hell and most of it depends on your luck and patience and that is the problem with it.

I understand how this game is based on patience, but that's not fun at all, and the high inclusion of luck is frustrating. this game does require a bit of skill, like differentiating sounds and knowing how to use the flashlight properly. but sometimes the whole CREW is on you almost all night. so the strategy in this game is if you haven't heard a noise in 8 seconds turn on your terminal but sometimes you won't get any peace at all! sometimes you just sit there doing nothing but going back and forth flashing the flashlight for multiple minutes, this game is the longest (in terms of the nights) and least fun FNaF game. 

Also, there is a certain gameplay thing that is literally 90% luck, i can't hear a THING with the printer, and when i do, by the time i shut off the terminal it's already too late and there are most of the time 2 animatronics at their final phase in my vents. 

Yes, you can just wait it out and wait for those rare moments of peace but it takes multiple minutes for them to stop! and when you die you have to do it allll over again. night 6 would be okay if it wasn't mandatory to finish the game but it is and i hate that, why is the main game of a FIVE nights at freddy's game 6 nights? 

If this game was only patience and skill, it could have been fun, but there is not enough skill, and too much luck. Difficulty doesn't make a game bad, that difficulty just needs to be fair, and the game needs to be enjoyable to excuse it. Not like this. 

BUT in defense of this game, you can disable the animatronics but it's not a five nights at freddy's game without them! you could play it as just a simulator but that would be incredibly boring. this game wasn't meant to be played without the animatronics. 
(FYI i went for the completion ending, i think that's the proper way to play it. but if you were going to get the mediocry ending i guess the game would be okay but for me it just wouldn't feel right.)

En el momento que escribo esta reseña habré estado unas dos semanas rejugando todos los juegos de la franquicia en orden. Pizzeria Simulator está bien, las capturas y el tráiler que aparecen en Steam supongo que son engañosos a posta, pues ese gameplay son solo los primeros 5 minutos de juego, luego es un FNAF de peso como cualquier otro. Y de verdad, me parece un FNAF con mecánicas buenas e interesantes (menos por una), pero no entiendo por qué tuvimos que volver a mecánicas de administración como en el FNAF 1.

Todas las noches resultan difíciles, lo cual de por sí no es un problema, debido a que esta vez atraes a los animatrónicos por sonido; mientras seas capaz de hacer tus tareas en silencio mientras los mantienes alejados de ti, estarás bien. ¿Obstáculo? La maldita ventilación. ¿Por qué era necesario hacer que la oficina se calentase? Si quitaran la mecánica del ventilador sería un FNAF perfecto, al igual que sus predecesores: Sister Location y FNAF 4. Y esto, para mí, es un problema porque me parece una forma demasiado básica de añadir dificultad, especialmente viniendo de los dos FNAF mencionados anteriormente.

Esto es solo mi opinión, claro, el juego como tal sigue estando bastante bien para ser gratis y a la mayoría le gustará, pero para mi estas mecánicas de administración milimétricas ya le quedaban pasadas a la franquicia. Si eres como yo y no te molan estas cosas, mírate el good ending y el lore ending en YouTube, esos dos finales son el único contenido de historia con bastante peso, lo demás son trámites.

149935120.review:
While I enjoyed the game enough to give it a review, it's absolutely the weakest in the FNAF series and only worth playing if you're into the lore of Midnight Motorist and Fruity Maze. I will say the pizzeria simulator parts are phenomenal and would've been better as a separate game, I especially love all of the minigames like Midnight Motorist or the Basketball arcade game. The salvage portion of the night is also very successful in my opinion, it is the only part of the game that evokes the horror of past FNAF titles. Sadly this is all invalidated with the office area, which is an absolute slog to get through. The inclusion of tasks instead of pure survival makes the later nights ridiculously hard, with some animatronics  (particularly Molten Freddy and Scrap Baby) travelling way too fast. Afton commonly ignores the audio lure as well, making turning the fan off and shining your light at the vent the best option to deal with him. The only issue with that is every other animatronic being left to the audio lure, with no opportunity to shine your light in the left vent. This game also shares a game-ruining issue with FNAF 4: terrible audio cues. Sometimes I will hear the lightest noise and get jumpscared, while other times the animatronics are literally whispering to me or making loud scraping noises while being nowhere near my office. It's an overall negative experience that drags down the game's replay ability, though I do still recommend it to FNAF fans.

For the lore and simulator segments I am giving this game a score of 7/10, but the office nights (particularly night six) borders on a 4/10.

149528753.review:
A Deliciously Terrifying Culinary Experience!

Five Nights at Freddy's Pizza Simulator is a game that takes the best elements of the franchise and serves them up in a whole new way. As a longtime fan of the series, I can confidently say that this entry is a delightful combination of horror and management gameplay that kept me hooked from start to finish.

The game starts innocently enough as you take on the role of a business owner tasked with running your own Freddy Fazbear's Pizzeria. You'll be in charge of designing your restaurant, ordering supplies, and trying to turn a profit while keeping everything running smoothly. It's a fantastic addition that adds a layer of complexity to the FNAF formula.

Of course, the real heart-pounding action begins when you're thrust into the night shifts, where you must fend off the terrifying animatronics that come to life after dark. The tension and jump scares are as nerve-wracking as ever, and the game doesn't pull any punches when it comes to keeping you on the edge of your seat. The atmosphere and sound design are masterful, immersing you in a chilling, haunting ambiance that's synonymous with the series.

What sets this installment apart is the variety of tasks you'll undertake to protect yourself from the animatronic horrors. You'll need to manage limited resources, allocate tasks efficiently, and even play mini-games that offer new twists and turns in the story. It adds a strategic layer to the familiar jump-scare gameplay that fans of the series will love.

Graphically, the game retains the creepy charm of its predecessors, with well-designed animatronics and a grimy, retro atmosphere that makes the experience all the more unsettling. The sound effects and voice acting are top-notch, enhancing the overall immersion and fear factor.

In conclusion, Five Nights at Freddy's Pizza Simulator is a worthy addition to the franchise, blending classic horror elements with new gameplay mechanics that make it stand out from the rest. It's a deliciously terrifying culinary experience that will keep you coming back for more, making it a must-play for fans of the series and horror game enthusiasts alike. Just remember, the pizza may be fake, but the scares are very real!

148529299.review:
It's free and the day time Pizzeria Tycoon sections are great. Other wise the game play is mediocre at best, and frustratingly confusing at worst. The visuals are great as per usual, and the easter eggs of this game are some of my favorite in the entire series.

Usually I wouldn't recommend a game like this due to its game play not being good, but I can't really fault a free game that was made to tie up certain aspects of the story, which I think it does fairly well. Night section game play is trash though, nothing good to be said about that.

147656258.review: This game is one of the scarier fnaf games imo. Cause in every other fnaf game, you getting through the night is determined by time which is a factor you cannot control. So your whole attention is put into surviving the animatronics themselves. But in pizzeria simulator you have to complete the tasks to finish the night. So you're the one that determines when the night is completed. This makes the jumpscares wayyy more startling and scary because when they happen its usually while you're doing a task, and your focus is on completing them which makes the jumpscares much more unsuspecting and scary.

That being said, I would still recommend this game. I still think it's one of the best games in the franchise.

145984804.review: This review contains spoilers but this game sucks so I don't think it matters if things are spoiled. I really should have taking the red flag here that this is the only FNAF game that's free. This game is boring. The arcade-like part of it at the beginning was interesting and I really miss playing it. I say that because once you complete it it is permanently unplayable. Even if you click new game you get presented with a second half of the game. I'm not sure if that's some sort of glitch or just a built-in troll but it's annoying. The second half of the game is boring. You have to sit through a very long colorful, explanation of some sort of franchise deal you're entering into. Then it plays like a mobile game where you set up your own pizzeria. And then finally when you get to something that might be mildly interesting, it's boring as heck. All you do is check the vents, do tasks on the computer, check the motion sensor, and try not to fall asleep while you're playing. The only time it starts getting mildly interesting is whenever you accidentally let one of the animatronic loose in the pizzeria by failing the salvage section that comes afterwards. The animatronic appears to be on the motion sensor for maybe one second. Trying to divert its attention does nothing except ensure you will die within the next 2 minutes. I am actually shocked that this game is so bad. This will be the last time I get a game from Scott, the creator of the FNF series, that's free. You truly get what you pay for.

145551058.review:
100% would recommend this game even if you aren't the biggest fan of jumpscares. it's very good overall despite it's detractors, especially considering it's free

[list]
[*]tycoon sections are the best bit out of the whole game personally. very fun, very funny ([i] shoutout helpy [/i]), and the games are good ([i] shoutout midnight motorist and fruit punch clown [/i]). absolutely [b] banging [/b] music, not sure if it was scott or somebody else who composed for the game but whoever did needs a raise. graphics are really impressive for a clickteam fusion game. not a huge amount to write home about, but that doesn't mean it's boring or bad or anything. just have more to say about the nights

[*]night sections are quite hard but that's probably because i'm stupid, i have to lean away from my monitor because i hate the jumpscares, and i'm too scared to play on my own so i play with my sister and she wears the headphones. personally found buying the upgrades for the computer basically required to get through the nights ([i] but remember, i'm dumb [/i]). i found motion detection [b] extremely [/b] useful, and i was using it almost every time i looked back at the computer. although, it can be a bit dodgy at times ([i] my sister was [b] convinced [/b] that lefty was in the building even though we hadn't salvaged him yet and we had no risk whatsoever because she saw four warning symbols on the motion detection. my theory is someone moved two times very quickly through the vents and it registered both movements, showing two warning symbols even though it was only one person [/i]). also used audio lures extremely frequently, but they are unreliable. turning off the fan while was my strat while printing things, but, without exaggeration, i have never turned the computer off, it's a complete waste. also i don't really get silent ventilation but i keep it on anyway.

[*]salvage sections are ok if you know what you're looking for, but can feel very unfair. firstly, i enjoy having the option between keeping the animatronic in the building or throwing it away. i don't like dealing with the animatronics in the vent sections, so still being able to still get different endings while not taking salvage is very nice for me. the idea of the animatronic losing value if you shock it too much did seem slightly pointless to me, ([i] as i said to my sister, i'd rather lose a little money from shocking it too much than dying and losing all of it [/i]). however i understand it was implemented to stop you from just shocking it all the time. the mechanic of the animatronics moving when you have the paper up is good in theory, and it is good, when you can tell they're going to attack. sometimes it's hard to determine when the animatronic is going to get you or is one phase away from getting you. they aren't consistent with their phases ([i] when we were doing springtrap salvage, first he moved straight to his 'ready to attack' phase even though we had only put the paper up literally one time, and we noticed he moved so we shocked him. later he very clearly moved, but to a different position, and i let my sister decide not to shock him, which thankfully was ok because he wasn't going to kill us in that position [/i]). i can ignore all of the weird phases and positions stuff, if it was just that, however there it an [b] utterly [/b] [u] horrid [/u] extra mechanic. the animatronic can produce a certain noise, kind of like clinking and whirring, and if you don't shock it when you can hear this noise, it kills you instantly. i cannot overstate how much i absolutely [b] despise [/b] this mechanic ([i] molten freddy was the only salvage we were able to get successfully on me and my sister's attempt at the true ending. springtrap was kinda nice and only killed us late into the salvage, so we thought maybe we missed his movement, but i still thought that death was kinda weird. baby killed us almost instantly, i think just about after the first audio prompt. i was [b] sure [/b] she hadn't moved. my sister was wearing the headphones for the salvages and when i told her about the certain noise, she told me to wear the headphones for lefty because she wasn't sure what to look for. [b] literally before the salvage had even started lefty was making the noise. [/b] that's not an exaggeration, when the audio stopped playing because we had the option between salvaging or throwing into the alley, i could hear it. the second we put the paper up we died. [/i]) so yeah maybe listen carefully.
[/list]

overall, the tycoon section is great, nights are difficult, and salvages are whatever ([i] although i am still a bit annoyed about losing all those salvages [/i]) would recommend even if just for a bit of silly fun
([i] edited because i am a dumb idiot with formatting[/i])

barrelling and near-flawless, always a bit disarming even tho i know whats coming. the office sections r predictably what broke me, much like fnaf4 the necessity of relying on subtle audio cues just combined rly badly with my sensory processing and the overwhelmingly vivid Aesthetic Horror (by far the best Shitty Office in this series), so i have to acknowledge my own limitations here unfortunately. i do genuinely love the design, it feels appropriately climactic as a Greatest Hits of all the previous games, including resurrecting my fave gameplay idea from sister location (disconnecting completion from a timer and instead putting it On U to finish the tasks at hand)...and ofc the contrast w/ the day sections is as vivid a demonstration as any of fnafs whole Something Menacing Hiding Under Something Innocent draw. famously this is also an excellent narrative crescendo, and the gravity of the true ending is a real testament 2 the contradicting facts that (1) fnaf prob should have had more straightforward narrative elements like this to rly get some vividness out of its material and (2) it kinda doesnt matter cuz weirdo jesus freak scott cawthon somehow pulled off the perfect magic trick anyway. like many ppl, my interest in these games narratively rly doesnt extend beyond the initial 6 games, which honestly might have less to do with the fact that theres Nothing Left To Do with the story and more with the fact that theyre never gonna pull off a magic trick like this again, and frankly given that fnaf is clearly now intended to be a Forever Property im not sure theyll even try. this is like the One Time that the series rly tried to say that everything Matters and that all yr investment was worth it, and ppl agreed. i do hope ill come back and experience everything for myself, i think its more likely here then fnaf 4, but as of now the dnf status is rly the only thing keeping me from confidently saying this is my fave game in the series

145281436.review: I've grown to really like this game over the years. After the release of this game, I kinda stopped following FNAF for a while, at least until Help Wanted came out. Honestly though? This game is really great, possibly one of the best games in the series. The tycoon section is easily the best part, it's really fun saving up your money to get some cool new games to play, or to get an expensive new animatronic. There's also multiple endings, incentivizing multiple playthroughs, and they're pretty fun to go for. The night sections are the weak link of the game, but once I figured out how they worked, they became a lot more satisfying to complete. It does take a while to figure out though, and I couldn't figure out what I was doing wrong for the longest time. It is cool that you can use multiple strategies to figure out how to survive, but a lot of them end badly, with some random chance elements being thrown in. I'm kinda glad this didn't get a custom night of its own, it would've been very difficult and frustrating. The salvage sections are really fun, and while I think the audio cues are too quiet to be noticeable, it does make them scarier overall. Story-wise, this game is really great. It ends the original story of FNAF in a very satisfying way, even if later games undo that. This game is a really solid package, and one of the best FNAF games in terms of replayability. It's also nice that it's free, Scott is such a real one for that.

“My friend, you have met a terrible, terrible demise. But, uh, y'know, I-I don't feel too bad about it. After all, if... if it weren't from me, it would've just been from someone else, y'know? I guess what I'm trying to say is, life... life goes on. W-well, from—for everyone else, life goes on. Not... not for you. You're... you're dead. But that's neither here nor there. It reminds me of one summer day in the park. I was having just a delightful picnic with my good friend Orville. And I said to him, I said, "Orville, I... I have a story." And he said to me, "What's the significance of the story?" And... I said to him, "Orville, not every story has to have significance, y'know? Sometimes, a... y'know, sometimes, a story's just a story. You try to read into every little thing, and find meaning in everything anyone says, you'll just drive yourself crazy. Had a friend do it once. Wasn't pretty. We talked about it for years. And then not only that, but... you'll likely end up believing something you shouldn't believe, thinking something you shouldn't think, o-o-or assuming something you shouldn't assume. Y'know? Sometimes," I said, "A story is-is just a story, so just be quiet for one second of your life and eat your sandwich, okay?" Of course, it was only then I'd realized I'd made sandwiches, and... poor Orville was having such difficulty eating it! Elephants have those clumsy hands, y'know? Actually, I-I suppose that's the problem. They don't have hands at all, do they? They're f—they're all feet! And I-I couldn't imagine someone asking me to eat a sandwich with my feet. Now, if I recall correctly, there was a bakery nearby. I said to him, "Orville, let me go get you some rye bread." Now, I'm unsure if elephants enjoy rye bread, but I assure you that Orville does. Now, this was on a Tuesday, which was good, because rye bread was always fresh on Tuesday. They made sourdough bread on Monday, and threw it out Wednesday... Or rather, they sold it at a discount for people wanting to feed it to the ducks, and then, prob'ly at the end of the day, finally, they threw it all out. I-I don't recall. I do remember a man who would bring his son to the bakery every Wednesday, and... then go feed the ducks. He would buy all of the sourdough bread. Of course, y'know, you're not supposed to feed the ducks sourdough bread at all. It swells up in their stomach, and then they all die. At, uh, at least... at least, that's what I've heard. Y'know, I-I never saw any ducks die myself, but I did notice a substantial decrease in the duck population over the course of a few years. I just never thought to stop the man and tell him that he was killing the ducks by feeding them sourdough bread! And if you want my opinion on the matter—heh, and I told Orville this as well—if you wanna feed ducks, or birds of any kind, for that matter, it's best to buy seed. I mean, when you think about it, breads of any sort don't occur in nature. They don't grow on trees o-or spring up from the bushes. I don't think birds know what to do with bread. What was I saying? Oh oh, yes yes. So I bought Orville some rye bread. What a fine day it was.”
-Mr. Hippo

144769786.review:
Freddy's Fazbear's Pizzeria Simulator provides lots of replay-ability and fun challenges for those who are interested in the horror franchise. There's seven known endings that you can get in the game, with each one rewarding you with a unique certificate offering a special accomplishment.

Scott mentioned in an interview that this game was created with the sole purpose being to tie together lose ends from all the other Five Nights At Freddy's games. With that being said, the story gives off a good sense of closure to those that have made their way through the series.

The game is also free, so you have nothing to lose by trying it!

It also has a decent amount of content to go through and, most interestingly, it's free. Check it out if you like horror games(or even if you don't), you won't lose much by doing so. 142166719.review:
Long story short, I do think fnaf 6 is the best in the series, and that's shocking considering this is one of the only two "free" fnaf games while the rest cost 5 or more bucks in USD.

Kinda ironic how out of all of them, this one is in my opinion the most deserving of that 5 dollar price tag but I digress.

I really love the gameplay loop of this game and how your decisions can have a big impact on how the rest of the game will play out for the remaining days and can make every playthrough unique, tense, and really fun.

Most of this game is designed really really well and I would highly recommend you play it.

However I did say "most" of this game is designed really well, I do think there is some core issues that need to be addressed in a possible sequel.

And I know you might be confused by that because FNAF has like a million sequels but when I say sequel, I mean specifically a sequel to this game's system's. Just a similar game (most likely a fan game), with some new bells and whistles, and much much needed quality of life improvements.


So without further ado, here is my list of issues with the game, and most of them stem from trying to get the "black listed" ending.


1: The game is a complete RNG fest once you take any form of risky action like increasing your risk or buying marked down items which has a small chance of letting an animatronic into the building. For the black listed ending you will need to rely on good mark downs to get this ending so it is very luck dependent.

Another thing is that the animatronics you let in turn the nights into slogs the more of them you let in and they can also be complete RNG fests as well; however I don't think they are nearly as bad as the simulation bit as you can retry the nights as much as you want until you hit the jackpot and win.

The same can't be said for the simulation tycoon bit however and speaking of that.


2: The game is basically on ironman mode. Meaning every decision you make is final. You cannot undo anything. The only thing you can redo is the night segments. 

This wouldn't be as much of a problem if a run of the game didn't take around 4 hours to complete and said run didn't require you to make constant committed decisions that can possibly mess up the run.

I think this game would be a lot better if you could make manual saves at certain points if the game is going to be as RNG dependent as it is for certain achievements.


3: This is one of those games that's more fun if you already know what you're doing but not as fun if you don't.

Simply put, this game suffers from the classic Pokemon trope of just telling you things exist but not necessarily explaining how you should be using them. You basically either gotta learn via trial and error or just look up a guide before you play.

Doesn't help that the community isn't very good at making strategy guides for the tycoon segment of this game. So perhaps down the line I'll share what I did in a guide to help people looking to get all endings in this game.


4: Options Menu, We NEED an options menu! Sometimes you just wanna listen to music while you play and turn off the music and sound but this game doesn't have it.


With that all said, that's my review. My final verdict is that I do indeed recommend this game and think it is a classic of the FNAF series that everyone should try, especially since it is free and easy to run on basically anything.

Your lust for blood has driven you in endless circles, chasing the cries of children in some unseen chamber, always seeming so near, yet somehow out of reach, but you will never find them. None of you will. This is where your story ends. And to you, my brave volunteer, who somehow found this job listing not intended for you, although there was a way out planned for you, I have a feeling that's not what you want. I have a feeling that you are right where you want to be. I am remaining as well. I am nearby. This place will not be remembered, and the memory of everything that started this can finally begin to fade away. As the agony of every tragedy should. And to you monsters trapped in the corridors, be still and give up your spirits. They don't belong to you. For most of you, I believe there is peace and perhaps more waiting for you after the smoke clears. Although, for one of you, the darkest pit of Hell has opened to swallow you whole, so don't keep the devil waiting, old friend. My daughter, if you can hear me, I knew you would return as well. It's in your nature to protect the innocent. I'm sorry that on that day, the day you were shut out and left to die, no one was there to lift you up into their arms the way you lifted others into yours, and then, what became of you. I should have known you wouldn't be content to disappear, not my daughter. I couldn't save you then, so let me save you now. It's time to rest - for you, and for those you have carried in your arms. This ends for all of us. End communication.
